WRITING.TITLE: Gamers and designers of Reddit: Is it better to play an old game you love, or a new game in a franchise you know well (but don't necessarily care for)?
WRITING.TEXT: Is it better to play someone old, that you've played many times and has had quite an impact on your life, or to play something you haven't played, but you know the franchise, the mechanics, the rough story line etc? Is the (relativity small) novel experience more valuable than the nostalgic experience?
I feel like I should know this, but what's that from?

WRITING.TITLE: How I feel upvoting a post on /new

WRITING.TEXT: Man, what kind of birthday songs are your friends and family into? That sounds messed up.
They will look up and ask "Tell us about Bryson" and I will whisper "no".

WRITING.TITLE: Should people pronounce words from a different language as they're pronounced in that language?
WRITING.TEXT:
This had bugged me for some time, being a Belgian studying in America. I grew up speaking Dutch and French, so whenever an American pronounces a typical Dutch/French word incorrectly, it gets under my skin. One recent example is my professors pronunciation of 'apartheid'. In Afrikaans or Dutch it should be pronounced something like 'apart hide', but my profs use the American 'th' pronunciation in the word.
Am I in the wrong here? If no, what are foreign words that get mispronounced that really bug you?
